revised_title: Maintenance of Genetic Polymorphism in Island Populations: Large Mammals in the Hebrides
tldr: This study investigates the maintenance of genetic polymorphism in small island populations of Red deer and Soay sheep in the Hebrides. The authors found that two processes help to mitigate the loss of genetic variation: selection and changes in the reproductive success of males. These findings challenge the conventional wisdom of population genetics theory, which predicts that fluctuations in population size and mating success should lead to loss of genetic variation.
